title: 103_hr429
content: The "Taxpayer Debt Buy-Down Act" designates amounts for the reduction of public debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a new part for the designation of funds towards reducing public debt. Every individual with adjusted income tax liability can designate up to 10 percent of their liability to reduce the public debt when filing their tax return. The designation must be made at the time of filing the return and on the first page or the page with the taxpayer's signature. Adjusted income tax liability refers to the income tax liability for the taxable year. The designation of income tax payments to the Presidential Election Campaign Fund must be made at the time of filing the return, either on the first page or the page with the taxpayer's signature. Adjusted income tax liability is the income tax liability for the taxable year. The amendments in this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment date. A new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code for a Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States for the purpose of paying off federal government obligations. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are appropriated to the Trust Fund, which can only be used to pay, redeem, or buy back government debt. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are used to pay, redeem, or buy back government debt. The Trust Fund can only be used for these purposes. The Public Debt Reduction Trust Fund is established to pay off federal government obligations. Amounts designated for public debt reduction are used to pay, redeem, or buy back government debt. The Trust Fund can only be used for these purposes. The amendments made by this section apply to amounts received after the date of the enactment of this Act. Part C of the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended by adding a new section for sequestration to reduce the public debt. Sequestration is mandated within 15 days after Congress adjourns, following any previous sequestration requirements. The amount is based on the estimated aggregate designated under the Internal Revenue Code for the last taxable year before the session, adjusted for discretionary spending reductions. The Internal Revenue Code mandates sequestration within 15 days after Congress adjourns, based on the estimated aggregate designated for the last taxable year, adjusted for discretionary spending reductions and deficit changes resulting from legislation. The absence of limits allows for a net deficit change from the baseline amount calculated under section 257, with the baseline for fiscal year 1996 and beyond based on fiscal year 1995 enacted appropriations less any 1995 sequesters. Each account of the United States is subject to reduction by a dollar amount calculated by multiplying the level of budgetary resources in that account by a uniform percentage to carry out the sequestration. Each account of the United States shall be reduced by a dollar amount calculated by multiplying the level of budgetary resources in that account by a uniform percentage to carry out the sequestration.
